stage01.Question:
When Mwansa was born, she cried a lot, and her mother doubted her breast milk was enough. A community member suggested giving her watery porridge.

What should Mwansa’s mother do?

Answers.Text: Keep breastfeeding every time Mwansa seems hungry.
Answers.Note: Exclusive breastfeeding is ideal. Breast milk provides all necessary nutrition for Mwansa’s first six months. The perfect balance of nutrients, antibodies, and enzymes are essential for a baby’s healthy development. Unclean water and liquids other than breastmilk can increase the risk of infections.

Answers.Text: Start giving her some watery porridge and see if it helps.
Answers.Note: Watery porridge is actually worse for Mwansa. Exclusive breastfeeding ensures all her nutritional needs are met and prevents potential sickness from unsafe sources. Her body isn't prepared for other foods yet. Introducing them won't provide enough essential nutrients that are crucial for a baby's growth and development.

stage01.Question:
Mwansa has just turned 1. Her mother knows a healthy diet is crucial for her development. A community health worker advised her about the importance of iron in their diet. With iron-rich foods being expensive, she must make cost-effective choices.

With an average income of $150 (3750 Zambian Kwacha (ZMW)) per month and a nutritious food basket costing $14.47 (ZMW 361.75),

What should she prioritise to improve their iron levels?

Answers.Text:
Paw paw cost:
$4.93 to $11.57 (ZMW 123.25 to 289.25) on average.
Answers.Note: Paw paws are low in iron, but high in Vitamin C, which aids iron absorption from plant-based foods. They're a healthy snack but don't directly address Mwansa’s iron issue.

Answers.Text:
Celeriac (Fortified Breakfast Cereal) cost:
$3.00 to $6.00 (ZMW 75 to 150) average per box.
Answers.Note: Many breakfast cereals are fortified with iron, but even the cheapest options come at a high cost for Mwansa’s mother, which could mean sacrificing protein intake for a few days.

Answers.Text:
Beans cost:
$1.00 to $3.00 (ZMW 25 to 75) average per 450 grams.
Answers.Note: Beans are a good choice for Mwansa’s mother. They provide about 6.6 mg of iron per cup, and 7 mg is the recommended daily iron intake for Mwansa’s age. This is a cost-effective solution.

stage01.Question:
Mwansa has been having an upset stomach and diarrhoea for more than a day. Her mother visits a local health worker, who emphasises good hygiene, like handwashing with soap, and gives her an oral rehydration solution for Mwansa. Afterwards, Mwansa’s mother passes by a street vendor selling soap.

Should her mother buy soap?

Answers.Text: Yes
Answers.Note: Mwansa feels better after the oral rehydration solution, and her mum's decision to buy soap ensures better hygiene at home. Regular and thorough hand washing removes harmful pathogens such as viruses and bacteria that can cause diarrheal illnesses.

Answers.Text: No
Answers.Note: Mwansa feels better after the oral rehydration solution, but poor hygiene at home leads to regular diarrhoea, hindering her growth, nutrition absorption, and eventually causing stunted growth from frequent infections.

stage02.Question:
Mwansa has not eaten much meat growing up and has recently started menstruating, making iron is even more crucial. She's at risk of anaemia, often feeling tired, struggling to focus at school, and forgetting information in class. She frequently misses school due to lack of washroom access, and the high cost and scarcity of sanitary pads.

With final exams next month, what should she do?

Answers.Text: Keep pushing through exams and try her best.
Answers.Note: Mwansa is struggling to focus on school so asking a trusted adult for help is wise. Beans, pumpkin leaves and kapenta (small dried fish) are affordable iron sources, and organisations like World Vision can help combat menstruation stigma. Every girl should try to stay in school until at least the age of 18.

Answers.Text: Ask her mother or a female school teacher for advice.
Answers.Note: Asking a trusted adult for help is wise. Affordable beans, pumpkin leaves and kapenta (small dried fish) can boost iron levels, and programmes exist to support girls with menstrual needs and stigma. Mwansa, and every girl, should be able to stay in school until the age of 18.

Answers.Text: Start selling tissues or snacks on the side of the road before school to help support her family and cover essentials, like sanitary pads and more protein sources.
Answers.Note: While earning money shows initiative, it might risk exploitation. Asking a trusted adult for help is better. Beans, pumpkin leaves and kapenta (small dried fish) are affordable iron sources, and programmes can assist with menstrual needs. Every girl should have the right to complete secondary school.

stage02.Question:
Mwansa has always been small for her age due to stunting before age 2. Poor rainfall in Zambia has severely impacted maize production. Food prices are high, making it hard for Mwansa’s family to have enough variety in their diets. Stunting has caused Mwansa to struggle with strenuous activities. She can either collect water from a nearby slow-moving stream or a borehole 2 km away (a 1 hour round trip).

What should Mwansa choose to do?

Answers.Text: Collect water from the nearby stream. This way, she doesn’t have to walk far, and the small fee to use the borehole can be spent on food.
Answers.Note: Surface water is often contaminated, posing a danger of parasites and germs, without treatment. This could make Mwansa and her family sick, resulting in healthcare costs and no extra money for food. Using the borehole is safer; if the distance is tough, Mwansa can ask a sibling for help.

Answers.Text: Force herself to make the journey to the borehole to access clean water, despite the longer distance.
Answers.Note: Going to the borehole is extra effort but ensures long-term health benefits for Mwansa and her family. Surface water contamination increases the risk for water-borne diseases and adds healthcare costs and no extra money for food. The borehole is a healthier option if the water is safely collected and stored.

stage02.Question:
Education is very important for Mwansa’s future. At 16, she is preparing for her upper secondary exam, while more than a quarter of girls her age have already dropped out. Secondary education has costs, with public school tuition ranging from ZMW 500 to 1,500 per term (about $30 to $90 USD).

Can her family afford to keep sending Mwansa to school?

Answers.Text: Yes
Answers.Note: Considering that the average income in Zambia is about ZMW 6,000 ($223) per month, it's unlikely Mwansa’s family can afford her school fees. However, completing her education greatly impacts her future opportunities. Girls who stay in school longer marry later, have healthier children, and better health and nutrition.

Answers.Text: No
Answers.Note: Education significantly affects Mwansa’s future prospects. Staying in school leads to later marriage, healthier children, and better health and nutrition. Despite these benefits, the high fees against an average income of ZMW 6,000 ($223) per month make it difficult for her family to continue paying school fees.

stage02.Question:
Mwansa is 15, and her parents want her to leave school and get married to relieve financial strain. She feels sad as some girls in her village are already married, and as a result, have dropped out of school. Mwansa wants to stay in school and marry later.

What should she tell her parents?

Answers.Text: Mwansa should tell her parents she doesn’t want to get married now, and ask a teacher or faith leader to discuss the importance of education with them.
Answers.Note: Child marriage affects 29% of girls in Zambia, although a new law makes it illegal. Mwansa should express her desire to stay in school. Her growth is incomplete, and pregnancy could lead to severe complications or death. Adolescent pregnancies, including unsafe abortions, are the leading cause of death for girls aged 15-19.

Answers.Text: Mwansa should accept the marriage and try to return to school later.
Answers.Note: Accepting marriage risks her never returning to school. Child marriage impacts 29% of Zambian girls, despite recent legislation. As Mwansa hasn’t completed growing, pregnancy could cause severe complications, increasing health risks. Pregnancy complications are the leading cause of death for girls aged 15-19.

stage03.Question:
Mwansa is now married and responsible for crops and food preparation. A drought in Zambia has devastated their maize crop, and she can't afford extra food from the market. Her husband gives her money, but only enough to buy some maize flour.

Should Mwansa start a business to cover the budget gap?

Answers.Text: Yes
Answers.Note: Mwansa considers starting a fritters (vitumbuwa) business for additional income, and thinks of reaching out to city relatives for job opportunities. However, a quarter of Zambian girls aged 15-19 are not in school or employed. Those who work, often earn less than men, about 23% less globally. With rising food costs, maintaining a healthy diet will be difficult.

Answers.Text: No
Answers.Note: While earning an income could help, it might not cover the cost of healthy foods. She hasn’t finished her education, making a well-paying job unlikely. Mwansa could contact relatives in the city for job leads. A quarter of girls aged 15-19 in Zambia are not in school or employed, and women typically earn less than men, impacting their  ability to maintain a healthy diet.

stage03.Question:
Mwansa, now 17, works 6 days a week at a local factory. Childhood malnutrition (stunting) makes her shorter and lighter than other employees. The work is tiring, pay is low, and she misses her village.

Should she stay working there?

Answers.Text: Mwansa should stay at the job.
Answers.Note: Statistically, those stunted in childhood earn less as adults; in Zambia, this might mean $231.88 (ZMW 5,797) less per capita annually. Mwansa’s choice to continue working reflects limited options, but city living costs are high, and accessing nutritious food is difficult due to prices. She depends on relatives' goodwill for support.

Answers.Text: Mwansa should leave the job and find other work.
Answers.Note: Childhood stunting often results in lower adult earnings; in Zambia, this could be $231.88 (ZMW 5,797) less annually. Mwansa's search for different work makes life unstable, as she balances factory work 6 days a week., The high cost of living and food prices complicate accessing fresh produce, leaving her reliant on relatives' goodwill.

stage03.Question:
Mwansa, still working at the factory, seeks to start a business. She's considering a market stall, a loan for a sewing machine to work as a seamstress, or a food business for labourers. However, she hasn't secured funding for any of her ideas.

What should Mwansa do?

Answers.Text: Mwansa should keep looking for a loan.
Answers.Note: Mwansa lacks savings to start a business, but could seek a microfinance organisation like Vision Fund for a small loan. This isn't easy. Malnutrition raises unemployment risk by 12%, and anaemia's long-term effects can reduce productivity and IQ. Women's height correlates to wages: every 1 cm increase predicts a 6% wage increase.

Answers.Text: Mwansa should stay at her current job and stop considering this idea of starting a business.
Answers.Note: If Mwansa stays, she may risk being fired due to malnutrition, which raises unemployment likelihood by 12%, impacting her economic stability.

stage03.Question:
Mwansa is pregnant and expecting her first child. She’s worried about not being able to work, feels extremely tired, and has been diagnosed with anaemia. She dislikes going to antenatal visits because her factory job doesn't permit breaks, and health workers are disrespectful towards her.

Should Mwansa continue attending her antenatal visits at the health centre?

Answers.Text: Yes
Answers.Note: Antenatal care visits are crucial as they provide essential health and nutrition services during pregnancy. Timely treatment for anaemia can reduce risks for Mwansa and improve her baby's chances of a healthy birth weight. She needs supplements and follow-up care from healthcare providers who can offer advice on affordable iron sources and enhance antenatal support.

Answers.Text: No
Answers.Note: Antenatal care is vital for providing necessary health and nutrition services during pregnancy. Addressing her anaemia promptly can lower risks and ensure a healthier birth for her baby. Mwansa requires supplements and ongoing care from healthcare providers for guidance on affordable iron sources and antenatal support.

stage03.Question:
Mwansa went to the health centre, where she received iron treatment and folic acid supplements after her anaemia improved. They advised her to eat well, have an extra meal, and rest during her pregnancy. As a pregnant adolescent, she must consume enough to support both her and her baby's development.

What should Mwansa do to ensure a healthy pregnancy for herself and her baby?

Answers.Text: Mwansa can ask her husband and relatives for support to maintain a healthy pregnancy.
Answers.Note: Mwansa may struggle to get family support. Rising food prices due to drought make it hard to access nutritious foods. Although her family can grow enough maize for a basic meal twice daily, they lack funds for essential protein and iron-rich foods. Over 48% of Zambians can't meet their minimum caloric needs. Mwansa should consult a community health worker for affordable, locally grown foods to enhance her nutrition.

Answers.Text: Mwansa should choose cheaper food and ensure she gets enough energy from her meals.
Answers.Note: While her family can make a basic meal with the maize they grow, they can't afford additional protein and iron-rich foods for Mwansa's pregnancy. Increased food prices mean many items are harder to find. Over 48% of Zambians struggle to meet caloric needs. Mwansa should reach out to a community health worker for advice on affordable, locally grown foods to improve her diet.
